Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/16/2017.

Description: Quest Diagnostics Inc. agreed to pay $6 million to resolve a lawsuit by the United States alleging that its Berkeley HeartLab Inc. unit violated the False Claims Act by paying kickbacks to physicians and patients to induce the use of Berkeley for blood testing services and by charging for medically unnecessary tests.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/blood-testing-laboratory-pay-6-million-settle-allegations-kickbacks-and-unnecessary-testing

Description: The settlement resolved allegations that certain clinical laboratories operated by Nichols Institute (owned by Quest) defrauded Medicare, Medicaid, TRICARE, the Defense Department's health care program, and the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP) by routinely billing for laboratory tests that were not medically necessary.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2001/January/002civ.htm

Description: Quest Diagnostics Incorporated and its subsidiary, Nichols Institute Diagnostics , entered into a global settlement with the United States to resolve criminal and civil claims concerning various types of diagnostic test kits that NID manufactured, marketed and sold to laboratories throughout the country until 2006. The payment of $302 million included a $40 million criminal fine and a $262 million civil settlement. Nichols entered a guilty plea and Quest entered into a non-prosecution agreement.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/quest-diagnostics-pay-us-302-million-resolve-allegations-subsidiary-sold-misbranded-test-kits

Description: Quest Diagnostics Incorporated, Summit Health, Inc., and Unilab Corporation entered into a $126,599.25 settlement agreement to resolve allegations that a Summit location in Michigan employed an individual to administer vaccinations who was excluded from participation in Federal health care programs, and a Unilab location in California employed a Quality Assurance Specialist who was excluded from participation in Federal health care programs.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Info Source: https://oig.hhs.gov/fraud/enforcement/cmp/cmp-ae.asp

Description: After it disclosed conduct to the Office of Inspector General pursuant to its Corporate Integrity Agreement, Quest Diagnostics, Incorporated agreed to pay $152,560.51 for allegedly violating the Civil Monetary Penalties Law by employing four individuals that it knew or should have known were excluded from participation in Federal health care programs.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Info Source: https://oig.hhs.gov/fraud/enforcement/cmp/reportable-events.asp

Description: The California Attorney General announced a $241 million settlement with Quest Diagnostics, the state's biggest provider of medical laboratory testing, of a lawsuit alleging illegal overcharges to the state Medicaid program.
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/attorney-general-kamala-d-harris-announces-241-million-settlement-quest

Description: Quest Diagnostics agreed to pay $12.4 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that one of its subsidiaries manufactured faulty medical-testing kits that resulted in inaccurate and unreliable laboratory tests that were billed to state Medicaid programs.
Info Source: Attorney General Announces Colorado Participates in $12.4 Million Multistate Settlement with New Jersey Company, States News Service, August 11, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: misleading marketing of nursing education programs
Info Source: Nursing Students to Benefit from $508,000 Health Care Settlement with Parent Company for Chambersburg & Waynesboro Hospitals, Targeted News Service, December 9, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: On December 7, 2021, Quest Diagnostics Incorporated entered into a $48,953.22 settlement agreement with OIG. The settlement agreement resolved allegations that Quest submitted claims to Medicare for specimen validity testing (SVT) in conjunction with claims for urine drug testing when SVT was a non-covered service.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Info Source: https://oig.hhs.gov/fraud/enforcement/quest-diagnostics-incorporated-agreed-to-pay-48000-for-allegedly-violating-the-civil-monetary-penalties-law-by-submitting-claims-for-non-covered-services/
